article:
The 'prefectures of [[Japan]]' are the country's 47 first-order subnational
jurisdictions on a state or provincial level: one , Tokyo; one , Hokkaido; two ,
Osaka and Kyoto; and 43 other . Prefectures are governmental bodies larger than
cities, towns, and villages. The former provinces of Japan were converted into
prefectures in the 1870s. Nussbaum, Louis-FrÃ©dÃ©ric.
(2002).
[http://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA780&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false
"Provinces and prefectures"] in Japan encyclopedia, p. 780.

The chief executive of each prefecture is a directly elected . Ordinances and
budgets are enacted by a unicameral (single chamber) whose elected members serve
four-year terms.

Under the current Local Autonomy Law, each prefecture is further subdivided into
and . Each district is further subdivided into and . For example, Hokkaido has
14 subprefectures which act as of the prefecture. Some other prefectures also
have branch offices, which carry out prefectural administrative functions
outside the capital. Tokyo, the capital, is a merged city-prefecture; it has
features of both cities and prefectures.
